subject: ACCT
title: Financial Accounting
description: Introduces the basic terminology, concepts, and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Concepts will include revenue and expense recognition, accounts receivable, inventory, long-lived assets, liquidity and solvency. Explores the income statement, balance sheet, and statement of cash flows, often using reports filed by publicly-traded companies. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: AFAM
title: Television and Crime
description: Examines crime dramas, reality television, news coverage, and crime documentaries. Analysis of how popular media shapes public views on criminality, law enforcement, violence, due process, and judicial responsibility. Pays attention to the historical relationship between media, crime, and the politics of race, class, gender, and sexuality. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: AMST
title: Terrorism and US Popular Culture
description: Explores the definitions, causes, consequences, and implications of terrorism through the lens of US popular culture. Primary sources include archives, movies, documentaries, novels, graphic novels, plays, autobiographies, television shows, oral histories, and photography. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: AMST
title: The Personal is Political: Ame...
long_title: The Personal is Political: American Essay Tradition
description: Explores the American essay tradition, offering students the opportunity to engage with some of its earliest moments as well as to some of its most recent iterations. Authors include Thomas Paine, Claudia Rankine, Benjamin Franklin, Samuel Delany, Michel de Montaigne, Joan Didion, Virginia Woolf, James Baldwin, Amber Hollibaugh, Audre Lorde, June Jordan, Sherman Alexie, Hilton Als, Esther Newton, and many more. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: AMST
title: Energy and the Environment in...
long_title: Energy and the Environment in American Culture
description: A historical survey of energy sources in American culture, from biomass to renewables. Secondary sources written by energy scholars will be supplemented with excerpts from novels, film clips, music, paintings, photographs, and other primary sources addressing each week’s theme. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: AMST
title: Asian Americans in Literature...
long_title: Asian Americans in Literature and Popular Media
description: Explores literature and popular media performances by Asian Americans, from 1945 to the present, in relationship to their historical contexts. Considers the changing ideas of “Asian American” as a category that both represents and makes culture. Attention to moving ideas of race, class, gender, sexuality, and citizenship. We will use a cultural studies approach to read and compare a variety of genres, including the novel, short story, television, standup comedy, and websites. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: AMST
title: U.S. Border & Immigration Policy
description: U.S. border and immigration policies at the national, state, and local levels from the colonial period to the present. The historical evolution of border and immigration policy; contemporary debates; the effects of shifting policy on immigrants of varying legal statuses. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: AMST
title: Inequality in America
description: The sociocultural dimensions of inequality in the contemporary United States.  Readings draw on work in anthropology, sociology, economics, history, cultural studies, and investigative journalism to examine how neoliberal policies, exacerbated by the Great Recession, impact Americans divided by identity categories such as race, class, gender, and citizenship. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: AMST
title: Film, Video, and American Hist...
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Civil War and Reconstruction, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, the Reagan era, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include films such as The Birth of a Nation, Modern Times, Dr. Strangelove, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ANTH
title: Introduction to Cultural Anthr...
description: An introduction to the central ideas, methods, and debates that make up the anthropological study of human thought and behavior. Survey of dynamic ways of life in many different societies; outline of the ways anthropologists have tried to understand societies. Hands-on ethnographic research provides insight into how cultural anthropologists do what they do—what problems they encounter and what tools and techniques they use for research and analysis. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. In this course students will think critically about the terms body, health, and medicine. Course readings, lectures, and in-class discussions will cover (but are not limited to) cross-cultural understandings of disability; embodied differences (race, gender, sexuality, disability); global and public health paradigms; and critical approaches to biomedicine. Transnational in scope and grounded in social science research, this course is highly recommended for any student considering a career in medicine. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ANTH
title: Forensic Anthropology
description: Hands-on introduction to forensic anthropology, using laboratory training, lectures, and case studies. Introduction to basic skeletal anatomy and use of recovered skeletal materials to assess a deceased individual's age, sex, height, ancestry, time of death, bone trauma, and disease. Additional topics include techniques for recovering human skeletal remains, reconstruction of faces, genetic identification, and medicolegal contexts of forensic anthropology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
long_title: The Genesis and Collapse of Old World Civilizations
description: Cancelled. The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to the earliest cities, states, and empires. Explores how these societies developed and why they collapsed. Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ANTH
title: The Sustainable Preservation o...
long_title: The Sustainable Preservation of Cultural Heritage: An Introduction to a Global Challenge of Our Time
description: This course is part of the IARU Global Summer Program. This course is open to Yale students and other IARU members only. The challenges of the 21st century in protecting the tangible and intangible, cultural and natural heritage of the world are global in character and need to be also addressed on a global level. Cultural and natural heritage are increasingly threatened with destruction not only by the traditional causes of decay, but also by changing social and economic conditions. For example, in the last years we have seen the phenomena of cultural cleansing rising in the Middle East and Africa, while natural disasters have taken a toll and underlined the need to develop sustainable and global strategies for preservation. This course offers an interdisciplinary approach to understanding the complex factors that challenge the preservation of cultural heritage. Guest speakers with relevant expertise will be invited to participate in many of the class sessions. In addition, the course will draw on the collections of the Yale University Museums for discussion and as the basis of student assignments. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ANTH
title: Southeast Asia in Context
description: Offered in Singapore. This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities' Global Summer Program. Southeast Asia in Context is a five-week exploration of Southeast Asia’s geographical, historical and cultural diversity. This course takes advantage of Singapore’s strategic position in offering a unique blend of classroom instruction at the NUS campus with hands-on fieldwork in other SE Asian countries. The lecturers are experienced teachers and researchers of Southeast Asia, who will explore themes such as Southeast Asian religion, archaeology, rural development, politics and regional integration. The field trip includes visits to magnificent ancient temples, rural agricultural communities, war memorials and a fair sampling of local village life that is well off the usual tourist track. Participants study two modules (choose 2 out of 3 elective modules) on Southeast Asian Studies with an anthropological and historical concentration. The first elective module, "SE2222: Southeast Asia In Context" provides a broad overview of Southeast Asia. The other two elective modules, “SE2880A: Southeast Asia's Cultural Mosaic" and “SE3214: Marketing Southeast Asia’s Heritage”, will equip students with the analytical tools for the comparative study of society and culture. SE2880A features a 7 to 9-day field trip to various religious and cultural sites in Indonesia while SE3214 will bring students to various field trips in Singapore. All three modules deploy 'context-based' learning by combining in-class instruction at NUS campus with local and regional hands-on experience of Southeast Asian life. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Singapore, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Yale Credit and 1 NUS Credit. Tuition: $4,810. Course dates: June 17 - July 22.

subject: ANTH
title: Inequality in America
description: The sociocultural dimensions of inequality in the contemporary United States.  Readings draw on work in anthropology, sociology, economics, history, cultural studies, and investigative journalism to examine how neoliberal policies, exacerbated by the Great Recession, impact Americans divided by identity categories such as race, class, gender, and citizenship. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ANTH
title: Men, Manhood, and Masculinity
description: Cultural and historic constructions of masculinity explored through an investigation of male bodies, sexualities, and social interactions. Multiple masculinities; the relationship between hegemonic, nonhegemonic, and subordinate masculinities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ANTH
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Examining how humans live in and understand their environment, the course will introduce anthropological approaches to ecological and environmental issues. Particular attention will be devoted to issues of environmental justice--the ways in which nature and natural resources have become a field of contestation and struggle--including those studied in the field of development and conservation, and to the study of disasters, including climate change and water-related dystopias. This course may serve as a good introduction for further courses on environmental anthropology, cultural ecology, political ecology, anthropology of disaster, environmental justice, anthropology of development and conservation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ANTH
title: Human Osteology
description: A lecture and laboratory course focusing on the characteristics of the human skeleton and its use in studies of functional morphology, paleodemography, and paleopathology. Laboratories familiarize students with skeletal parts; lectures focus on the nature of bone tissue, its biomechanical modification, sexing, aging, and interpretation of lesions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: APHY
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Examination of the science behind selected advances in modern technology and implications for public policy, with focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance. Topics are developed by the participants with the instructor and with guest lecturers, and may include nanotechnology, quantum computation and cryptography, renewable energy technologies, optical systems for communication and medical diagnostics, transistors, satellite imaging and global positioning systems, large-scale immunization, and DNA made to order. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: APHY
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Tours of energy facilities on the Yale campus. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 28 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: APHY
title: MultivariableCalculusEngineers
description: The course will introduce the engineering and applied science student to multivariable calculus for use in solving problems of physical interest. The course will focus on topics including three-dimensional spaces and vectors, vector-valued functions, partial derivatives, multiple integrals, and vector calculus including Greens', Stokes' and the divergence theorems. Prerequisite: MATH 115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: APHY
title: Ordinary and Partial Different...
long_title: Ordinary and Partial Differential Equations with Applications
description: Basic theory of ordinary and partial differential equations useful in applications. First- and second-order equations, separation of variables, power series solutions, Fourier series, Laplace transforms. Prerequisites: ENAS 151 or equivalent and knowledge of matrix-based operations. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4..

subject: ARBC
title: Elementary Modern Standard Ara...
description: Development of a basic knowledge of Modern Standard Arabic through a comprehensive and integrated method emphasizing reading, writing, speaking, comprehension, grammar, and vocabulary acquisition. Credit only on completion of ARBC S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ARBC
title: Elementary Modern Standard Ara...
description: Continuation of ARBC S110. Prerequisite: ARBC S110, 110a or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ARBC
title: Intermediate Modern Standard A...
description: Offered in Rabat, Morocco. This course is designed to improve students’ proficiency in aural and reading comprehension as well as in speaking and writing. It also aims to develop a strong understanding of the linguistic features of the Arabic language with emphasis on comprehensive communication skills. Students will have 4 hours of MSA on a daily basis, along with 4 hours of Moroccan Arabic per week. Prerequisite: ARBC 120 (Elementary Modern Standard Arabic II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with ARBC S140. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15.<\b> Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Rabat and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of ARBC S140). Tuition: $3,900. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ARBC
title: Intermediate Modern Standard A...
description: Offered in Rabat, Morocco. This course is designed to improve students’ proficiency in aural and reading comprehension as well as in speaking and writing. It also aims to develop a strong understanding of the linguistic features of the Arabic language with emphasis on comprehensive communication skills. Students will have 4 hours of MSA on a daily basis, along with 4 hours of Moroccan Arabic per week. Prerequisite: ARBC 120 (Elementary Modern Standard Arabic II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with ARBC S130. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15.<\b> Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Rabat and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $3,900. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ARBC
title: Advanced Arabic
description: Offered in Rabat, Morocco. First part of an accelerated language course. Includes readings, composition exercises, review of Arabic grammar, listening skills, and conversation practice in standard Arabic. Concentration is placed on idiomatic expressions, vocabulary acquisition, in addition to focusing on reading and listening to extended passages. Prerequisite: ARBC 140 (Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with ARBC S151. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Rabat and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 (credit only on completion of ARBC S151). Tuition: $3,800. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ARBC
title: Advanced Modern Standard Arabi...
description: Offered in Rabat, Morocoo. Second part of an accelerated language course. Includes readings, composition exercises, review of Arabic grammar, listening skills, and conversation practice in standard Arabic. Concentration is placed on idiomatic expressions, vocabulary acquisition, in addition to focusing on reading and listening to extended passages. Prerequisite: ARBC 140 (Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with ARBC S150. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Rabat and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1. Tuition: $3,800. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ARCG
title: The Genesis and Collapse of Wo...
long_title: The Genesis and Collapse of World Civilizations
description: The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to the earliest cities, states, and empires. Explores how these societies developed and why they collapsed. Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ARCG
title: Human Osteology
description: A lecture and laboratory course focusing on the characteristics of the human skeleton and its use in studies of functional morphology, paleodemography, and paleopathology. Laboratories familiarize students with skeletal parts; lectures focus on the nature of bone tissue, its biomechanical modification, sexing, aging, and interpretation of lesions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ART
title: Visual Thinking
description: An introduction to the language of visual expression, using studio projects to explore the fundamental principles of visual art. Students acquire a working knowledge of visual syntax applicable to the study of art history, popular culture, and art. Projects address all four major concentrations (graphic design, printing/printmaking, photography, and sculpture). 1 Credit. Tuition: $4,100. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ART
title: Basic Drawing
description: An introduction to drawing, emphasizing pictorial syntax and the articulation of space. Class work is based on observational study. Assigned projects address fundamental technical and conceptual problems suggested by historical and recent artistic practice. No prior drawing experience necessary. Enrollment limited to 20 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $4,100. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ART
title: Painting Basics
description: An introduction to basic painting issues, stressing a beginning command of the conventions of pictorial space and the language of color. Class assignments and individual projects explore technical, conceptual, and historical issues central to the language of painting. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $4,100. Session B: July 3-August 4.

subject: ART
title: Introduction to Digital Photog...
description: Exploration of the transition of photographic processes and techniques into digital formats. A range of tools are presented including scanning, digital cameras, retouching, color correction, basic composition, and inkjet printing. Students produce original work throughout the technical component of the class. After mastering the basics, students work toward the completion of a final project, and the focus of the remaining classes is on critiques. Throughout the term, lectures and presentations raise critical issues concerning the impact of digital applications and by-products on the medium of photography. Students must have access to a digital camera and bring it to class. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $4,100. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ART
title: Cinematic Storytelling in Prague
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Intensive, hands-on exploration of film history, theory and practice, offered in partnership with FAMU, the national film and television academy of the Czech Republic, Europe’s top film school. Theory, tools, and techniques and practical skills—from operating a 16mm film camera to recording dialogue to lighting a set—which they will apply in the production of a weekly film project. During the third week of the program, students will travel to the beautiful spa town of Karlovy Vary (Carlsbad) to attend the world-renowned Karlovy Vary International Film Festival. The program includes a two-week mini course in Czech language and culture. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Prague and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,800. Course Dates: June 5 - July 7.

subject: ART
title: Introduction to Interactive De...
description: Interactive design explored through the development of projects that are based online. Concepts of prompt, feedback, and variable conditions; Web-specific design issues such as navigation and pacing, as well as design for variable sizes and devices; best practices in code craft and design. The Web as a social ecosystem in which time and performance play important roles. Instruction in HTML, CSS, and some Javascript. No prior programming experience required. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $4,100. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ART
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Introduction to the principals, history, and practice of animation in visual art and film. With a primary focus on production, this course utilizes historical and theoretical developments in 20th and 21st Century animation as a framework for making digital animation. Production focuses primarily on digital stop-animation and compositing, as well as 2D and 3D computer-generated animation. Students gain an understanding of the principals of animation and develop fundamental skill-sets in Apple Final Cut Pro, Adobe After Effects, and Autodesk Maya 2012. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $4,100. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ASTR
title: Galaxies and the Universe
description: A nontechnical introduction to stellar populations and the structure and evolution of the Milky Way galaxy; external galaxies, radio galaxies, and quasars; cosmology and the expanding universe. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ASTR
title: Archaeoastronomy
description: Online Course. An introduction to how celestial patterns and events were observed and interpreted up to the Copernican revolution. Ancient observatories, calendar systems, records of astronomical events, and the role of astronomical knowledge in culture. Exercises in naked-eye observation of the sky. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Technology fee $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: BIOL
title: Biochemistry, Biophysics, and...
description: Introduction to the study of life at the molecular level and to cell biology and membrane physiology. Topics include the three-dimensional structures and function of large biological molecules, the human genome, the design of antiviral drugs to treat HIV/AIDS, organization and functional properties of biological membranes, membrane physiology and signaling, rough endoplasmic reticulum and synthesis of membrane/secretory membrane proteins, endocytosis, the cytoskeleton, and cell division. Covers the material of BIOL 101 and 102, the first half of the yearlong introductory biology sequence. Followed in the summer by BIOL S106. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: BIOL
title: Genes, Ecology, and Evolutiona...
description: Introduction to genes, genetics, developmental biology, ecology, evolutionary biology, animal behavior, and the history of life. How genes control development and disease; Mendel's rules; examples of organ physiology; evolutionary transitions and natural selection; adaptation at genic, chromosomal, cellular, organismal, and supra-organismal levels; distributional and social consequences of particular suites of organismal adaptations. Covers the material of BIOL 103 and 104, the second half of the yearlong introductory biology sequence. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and 102 or BIOL S105. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: BIS
title: Accelerated Biostats: Accelera...
description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides a comprehensive introduction to the use of statistics in the fields of epidemiology, public health, and clinical research. Students gain experience conducting and interpreting a broad range of statistical analyses. Topics include descriptive statistics, rules of probability, probability distributions, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, sample size estimation, analysis of variance, nonparametric tests, and linear regression. Through computer laboratory sessions, students become familiar with the SAS statistical software package. Course is worth 2 course units.
Enrollment limited to students in the Advanced Professional M.P.H. and Accelerated M.B.A./M.P.H. programs. Auditors are not allowed.

subject: BRST
title: The British Empire and Its Imp...
long_title: The British Empire and Its Imperial Hub
description: Exploration of the rise, dominance, and decline of the British Empire, the unprecedented global system of political rule, military activity, and economic and cultural interactions. Consideration of London as a lens through which to think about the empire and of the British Empire as a means to think about London as an imperial capital. Weekly excursions to sites where the empire and its memory are embedded into the fabric of London. This course is part of the Yale in London summer session, and will be taught entirely in London, based at the Paul Mellon Centre.

subject: BRST
title: Queenship and Female Power fro...
long_title: Queenship and Female Power from the Tudors to the Modern Age
description: Examination of the nature of queenship and female power from the first 16th century experience of female rule through to Elizabeth II, the current monarch. This is not a biographical course: the lives of queens will be used as a means for examining the issues which sprang to the fore with the accession of the first ruling queen of England, Mary I, and the ways in which British queenship evolved over the past five centuries, as social and political ideas shifted and influenced the nature and perceptions of female rule. This course would be pertinent to students interested in British History or women’s studies/gender history.

subject: BRST
title: Modern British Drama
description: A detailed study of representative works of modern British drama, based on current productions on the London stage. Theatrical conventions developed by playwrights and actors in the theater of postwar Britain, both on the fringe and in the mainstream of the West End. Attention to social issues addressed by the plays.

subject: CDE
title: Soc&BehavFoundof Health: Accl...
description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides students with an introduction to social and behavioral science issues that influence patterns of health and health care delivery. The focus is on the integration of biomedical, social, psychological, and behavioral factors that must be taken into consideration when public health initiatives are developed and implemented. This course emphasizes the integration of research from the social and behavioral sciences with epidemiology and biomedical sciences.
Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: CDE
title: Accelerated Epidemiology
description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides a comprehensive overview of epidemiologic concepts and methods. Topics include measurements of disease frequency and association, study design (including randomized and non-randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, and ecologic studies), screening principles, reliability and validity, bias, confounding, and effect modification. After completing this course, students are able to calculate and interpret epidemiologic parameters, identify the strengths and weaknesses of various study designs, and apply the principles and methods of epidemiology to the design and analysis of new studies.
Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.

subject: CENG
title: Intro to Chemical Engineering
description: An introduction to chemical engineering including the profession, process design, and chemical engineering analysis. Prerequisite: MATH 112, 115 or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: CENG
title: Chemical Engineering Thermodyn...
description: Analysis of equilibrium systems. Topics include energy conservation, entropy, heat engines, Legendre transforms, derived thermodynamic potentials and equilibrium criteria, multicomponent systems, chemical reaction and phase equilibria, systematic derivation of thermodynamic identities, criteria for thermodynamic stability, and introduction to statistical thermodynamics. Prerequisite: MATH 120 or ENAS 151 or permission of instructor. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: CGSC
title: Mental Lives of Babies and Ani...
long_title: Mental Lives of Babies and Animals
description: Offered Online. Interdisciplinary exploration of the cognitive, social, and emotional capacities of creatures lacking language and culture. The extent to which our complex psychology is unique to mature humans; the relative richness of a mental life without language or culture. Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: CGSC
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Online Course. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 29 - June 30 (CRN 30134) and Session B: July 3 - August 4 (CRN 30137).

subject: CGSC
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Online Course. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 29 - June 30 (CRN 30134) and Session B: July 3 - August 4 (CRN 30137).

subject: CHEM
title: Chemistry in Context
description: Chemistry studied in the context of major contemporary issues, such as climate change, environmental degradation, renewable energy, and pharmaceutical developments. This course takes an interactive approach to learning chemistry with demonstrations and hands-on experience. Activities will highlight chemical reactions in fuel cells, properties of acid rain, nylon production, radioactivity, and more. Does not satisfy premedical chemistry requirements or requirements for the Chemistry major. Not open to students who have completed another chemistry course at Yale. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: CHEM
title: General Chemistry Laboratory I
description: Laboratory techniques required for qualitative and quantitative analysis, synthesis of inorganic compounds, and simple thermodynamic measurements. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S161 or subsequently. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,950. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: CHEM
title: General Chemistry Laboratory II
description: Laboratory techniques required for qualitative and quantitative analysis, synthesis of inorganic compounds, and simple thermodynamic measurements. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S165 or subsequently. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,950. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: CHEM
title: General Chemistry I
description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive, inorganic, and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Session A: stoichiometry, atomic structure, chemical bonding, molecular structure, gas laws, properties of solutions. These courses (CHEM S161/S165) with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: CHEM
title: General Chemistry II
description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Session B: chemical kinetics and thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, acid-base theory, electrochemistry, transition metal chemistry, introduction to organic chemistry. Prerequisite: CHEM S161. These courses (CHEM S161/165) with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Chemistry
description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session A: structure and bonding, chemical energetics, stereochemistry, alkanes, nucleophilic substitution, infrared spectroscopy, alkenes and alkynes, alcohols and ethers. These courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, satisfy departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. For college students and beyond. After college-level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: CHEM
title: Organic Chemistry
description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session B: aldehydes and ketones, strategies in organic synthesis, carboxylic acid derivatives, carbonyl condensation reactions, sulfur and phosphorus compounds, bifunctional molecules, carbohydrates, organic nitrogen compounds, amino acids and proteins. These courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, satisfy departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. For college students and beyond. After college-level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: CHEM
title: Lab for Organic Chemistry
description: Introductory laboratory course covering basic synthetic and analytic techniques in organic chemistry. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S-220 or subsequently. For college students only. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses (CHEM S-222/S-223) must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,950. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: CHEM
title: Lab for Organic Chemistry
description: Introductory laboratory course covering basic synthetic and analytic techniques in organic chemistry. May be taken concurrently with CHEM S-221 or subsequently. For college students only. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses (CHEM S-222/S-223)must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,950. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: CHLD
title: Autism and Related Disorders
description: Online Course. Survey of current understandings and treatment of autism from infancy through adulthood. Topics include etiology, diagnosis and assessment, treatment and advocacy, and social neuroscience methods. Focus on ways in which research findings are integrated into diagnosis and treatment practices. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: CLCV
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: CPSC
title: Internet and Telecommunication...
description: The Internet is integral to our daily lives, in ways both obvious and not. Yet not many of us know how this technology works or know the legal and public policy issues which have a direct bearing on our use of this technology. This course will explore some of the cutting edge legal and public policy issues concerning the Internet and telecommunications. Issues to be explored include: Network Neutrality, Wi-Fi, Mobile Networks, and Over-the-Top Convergence. No previous experience with computers or law necessary. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29-June 30.

subject: CZEC
title: In Prague Film and Fiction
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, language, and film-making practicum. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students choose either FILM or CZEC credit. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Prague and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: June 26 - July 28.

subject: E&EB
title: Human Osteology
description: A lecture and laboratory course focusing on the characteristics of the human skeleton and its use in studies of functional morphology, paleodemography, and paleopathology. Laboratories familiarize students with skeletal parts; lectures focus on the nature of bone tissue, its biomechanical modification, sexing, aging, and interpretation of lesions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Microeconomics
description: Online Course. Introduction to the principles of microeconomics, supply and demand, consumer theory, and competitive markets. Applications to contemporary policy issues such as rent control, minimum wage, antitrust policy, pollution, and income inequality. For college students and beyond. May not be taken after ECON 108 or 110. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 29 - June 30 (CRN 30037) and Session B: July 3 - August 4 (CRN 30038).

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Microeconomics
description: Online Course. Introduction to the principles of microeconomics, supply and demand, consumer theory, and competitive markets. Applications to contemporary policy issues such as rent control, minimum wage, antitrust policy, pollution, and income inequality. For college students and beyond. May not be taken after ECON 108 or 110. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 29 - June 30 (CRN 30037) and Session B: July 3 - August 4 (CRN 30038).

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
description: An introduction to basic macroeconomic concepts and theories, such as national income accounting, theories of growth, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policy, banking, finance, and economic crises, with special emphasis on the recent financial crisis. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, 115 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Offered in both Session A: May 29-June 30 (CRN 30039) and Session B: July 3 - August 4 (CRN 30040).

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
description: An introduction to basic macroeconomic concepts and theories, such as national income accounting, theories of growth, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policy, banking, finance, and economic crises, with special emphasis on the recent financial crisis. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, 115 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Offered in both Session A: May 29-June 30 (CRN 30039) and Session B: July 3 - August 4 (CRN 30040).

subject: ECON
title: Econometrics and Data Analysis I
description: Online Course. Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Methods of evaluating quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After introductory microeconomics and MATH 112 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 29-June 30(CRN 30041) and Session B: July 1 - August 4 (CRN 30042).

subject: ECON
title: Econometrics and Data Analysis I
description: Online Course. Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Methods of evaluating quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After introductory microeconomics and MATH 112 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 29-June 30(CRN 30041) and Session B: July 1 - August 4 (CRN 30042).

subject: ECON
title: Game Theory
description: An introduction to the theory of multiperson decision problems and its application in economic analysis. Discussion of static and dynamic noncooperative games with particular attention to the notions of Nash equilibrium and sub-game perfect equilibrium. Prerequisite: two terms of introductory economics (ECON 115 and 116 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ECON
title: Introduction to Corporate Fina...
description: This course will develop techniques used in finance. Investment securities, options, risk, and portfolio selection will be studied. Through problem sets, quizzes, and class examples students will apply knowledge of financial concepts. Prerequisite: ECON 115 or equivalent. No prior knowledge of finance is required. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ECON
title: Private Law and Contract Enfor...
long_title: Private Law and Contract Enforcement in the United States and France
description: Offered in Paris, France. Parties engaging in economic exchange often organize their relationships through contracts and other private legal structures. The organization of exchange and the body of law and private institutions that govern and influence its structure. Substantive theoretical component and practical component, with on-site modules at the International Court of Commercial Arbitration in Paris. A comparative legal and institutional approach will be maintained throughout. Prerequisite: ECON 121 (Intermediate Microeconomics), MATH 112 (Calculus of Functions of One Variable I), or permission of instructor. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: June 26 - July 28.

subject: ECON
title: Causes and Consequences of Cor...
description: Online Course. Corruption, a manifestation of the principal-agent problem, is an obstacle to economic efficiency. Corruption occurs where fundamental institutions are weak or poorly designed, while situation-specific incentives make corruption tempting, and personal ethics are malleable. This course examines the economic, cultural, and political causes and consequences of corruption; cross-country comparisons of corruption levels; and examples of successful reforms and policies to combat corruption in bureaucracy and business. This summer, the textbook and the course materials have been updated. For college students and beyond. Prerequisite: ECON 110 or 115, or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ECON
title: Topics in International Econom...
description: Recent developments in international economics. Trade policy and market structure; the economics of trading blocs such as the EU and NAFTA; the economic consequences of continued U.S. external deficits; globalization and inequality; exchange rates, interest rates, and volatility; speculative capital flows and exchange rate policies; and financial crises and the prospects for the European Monetary Union. Prerequisites: intermediate microeconomics and macroeconomics or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: EENG
title: The Digital Information Age
description: An introduction to information transmission and storage and their impact on society. Technological issues and trade-offs that affect the design of digital systems. Elementary circuits and computer logic; sensors and actuators; signal processing and design for data transmission; information transmission on the World Wide Web. Projects include analysis and design using MATLAB. Intended for students in the humanities and social sciences and for freshmen considering a major in electrical engineering. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: EENG
title: The Science of Science Fiction
description: An exploration of the scientific basis, and inaccuracies, of modern science fiction. Technologies explored include nanotechnology, the theory of relativity, information technology, and environmental sustainability and terraforming. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENAS
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Examination of the science behind selected advances in modern technology and implications for public policy, with focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance. Topics are developed by the participants with the instructor and with guest lecturers, and may include nanotechnology, quantum computation and cryptography, renewable energy technologies, optical systems for communication and medical diagnostics, transistors, satellite imaging and global positioning systems, large-scale immunization, and DNA made to order. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENAS
title: Energy, Engines & Environment
description: Energy sustainability and global warming; thermodynamic fundamentals; engines (combustion technologies, fossil-fuel pollution, carbon capture and sequestration). Wind, solar, biomass, and other renewable energy sources. Designed for freshmen and sophomores in science and engineering and for non–science majors. Prerequisite: A score of 4 or 5 on Advanced Placement examinations in mathematics and/or science. 1 Credit. Tuition: 3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENAS
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Tours of energy facilities on the Yale campus. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 28 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ENAS
title: Introduction to Computing for...
long_title: Introduction to Computing for Engineers & Scientists
description: An introduction to the MATLAB and C programming languages for solving a variety of problems encountered in engineering, mathematics, and the natural sciences. General programming techniques, data analysis, numerical simulations, and transmission of data files between programs. Projects include processing microphone speech and digital images. Prerequisites: Math 115 or equivalent. Recommended preparation: previous programming experience. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENAS
title: MultivariableCalculusEngineers
description: The course will introduce the engineering and applied science student to multivariable calculus for use in solving problems of physical interest. The course will focus on topics including three-dimensional spaces and vectors, vector-valued functions, partial derivatives, multiple integrals, and vector calculus including Greens', Stokes' and the divergence theorems. Prerequisite: MATH 115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENAS
title: Ordinary and Partial Different...
long_title: Ordinary and Partial Differential Equations with Applications
description: Basic theory of ordinary and partial differential equations useful in applications. First- and second-order equations, separation of variables, power series solutions, Fourier series, Laplace transforms. Prerequisites: ENAS 151 or equivalent and knowledge of matrix-based operations. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ENGL
title: Writing Seminars I
description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3-August 4.

subject: ENGL
title: Writing Seminars I
description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3-August 4.

subject: ENGL
title: Reading and Writing the Modern...
long_title: Reading and Writing the Modern Essay
description: Close study of selected works of nonfiction prepares students to become critical readers and to apply professional strategies to their own writing. Readings from such authors as Joan Didion, Malcolm Gladwell, Maxine Hong Kingston, Emily Naussbaum, George Orwell, Brent Staples, and Alice Walker. Written assignments, involving frequent revision, include autobiography, profile, cultural critique, and humor. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ENGL
title: Reading and Writing the Modern...
long_title: Reading and Writing the Modern Essay
description: Online Course. Close study of selected works of nonfiction prepares students to become critical readers and to apply professional strategies to their own writing. Readings from such authors as Joan Didion, Malcolm Gladwell, Maxine Hong Kingston, Emily Naussbaum, George Orwell, Brent Staples, and Alice Walker. Written assignments, involving frequent revision, include autobiography, profile, cultural critique, and humor. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Technology fee $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENGL
title: Readings in American Literature
description: This course serves as both an introduction to as well as an exploration of American literature from the nineteenth century to the present. We will ask many questions of these texts, not the least of which is “what do we mean when we say ‘American?’” Given the wide range of the body of work that comprises American literature, however, we will also periodically ask in passing what we mean by “literature,” so as to consider what roles the literary plays in creating and shaping the possibilities of social imagination, private and public discourse, as well as one’s own identity. Emphasis on analytical reading, critical writing, and class discussions. Authors include Melville, Poe, Hawthorne, Whitman, Dickinson, Barnes, Toomer, H. Crane, W. C. Williams, L. Hughes, and M. Robinson. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENGL
title: Reading Fiction for Craft
description: Fundamentals of the craft of fiction writing explored through readings from classic and contemporary short stories and novels. Focus on how each author has used the fundamentals of craft. Writing exercises emphasize elements such as voice, structure, point of view, character, and tone. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENGL
title: Introduction to Writing Fictio...
long_title: Introduction to Writing Fiction and Creative Nonfiction
description: Conducted as a workshop, this course offers students the opportunity to write fiction and the particular sort of nonfiction that reflects and explores the narrative of their own lives. The focus will be on elements common to all storytelling, among them, character, narrative development, voice, and clarity of language and thought. Students may concentrate on a single genre, or, if they wish, experiment with both. Readings will include selections from contemporary American fiction and creative nonfiction. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be submitted with the online application. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ENGL
title: Shakespeare: Comedies and Roma...
description: Love, sex, gender, society, and theater practice in Shakespeare's comic genres, from the early farces and romantic comedies to the problem plays and late romances. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4. .

subject: ENGL
title: Shakespeare: Histories and Tra...
description: Study of three histories and seven tragedies at the pinnacle of Shakespeare's career. Focus on the source of each play's pathos and the nature of its poetic sublimity; some attention to performance and to the relation between the genres of history and tragedy. Extensive practice in writing short and medium-length critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read Julius Caesar. (The Signet edition, ordered through The Yale Bookstore, is preferred, but the Norton genre volumes are especially handsome substitutions; the Arden single play editions are more than acceptable if their price is not intimidating.) The regular course meetings will be supplemented by six evening screenings, and students are required to attend at least four of these. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENGL
title: American Literary Regionalism
description: This course will examine the phenomenon of regionalism in American literature. We will primarily study texts from the height of the regionalist movement; but we will also consider whether regionalism can be considered a contemporary (or continuous) literary phenomenon. Authors will include Willa Cather, Charles Chesnutt, William Faulkner, Sarah Orne Jewett, Edith Wharton, and Mark Twain. Prerequisite: at least one college-level literature course. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ENGL
title: Milton
description: Online Course. A study of Milton's major poetry, with attention to his relation to the cultural, social, and political struggles of the Puritan Revolution. Students will watch or listen to pre-recorded lectures, and will meet online for biweekly seminar discussions. Satisfies pre-1875 requirement. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENGL
title: Travel Writing
description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Examines travel writing, surveying a wide range of works, from long-form place essays to destination articles, from travel memoir to adventure odysseys. Readings include, Paul Theroux, Ryszard Kapuscinski, Jan Morris, and Pico Iyer. How voyages lend travel writers structure: a natural beginning, middle, and end. Students are encouraged to take advantage of their geographic mobility for their assignments and tasked to find an innovative mode or vehicle of exploring their chosen place. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Auvillar and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2 . Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: July 10 - August 4.

subject: ENGL
title: Modernism, Literature and Arts
description: Survey of the modern movement in Western European literature and art from the mid-nineteenth century to the mid-twentieth century. Writers include Baudelaire, Ibsen, Wilde, Yeats, H.D., Pound, Stein, Eliot, Mann, Proust, Joyce, Woolf, and Beckett. Consideration of movements in the visual arts from impressionism to surrealism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4..

subject: ENGL
title: Modern European Drama
description: The major European playwrights active from 1879 (the premiere of Ibsen's A Doll’s House) to 1989 (the death of Beckett) were responsible for theatrical advances of continuing influence and importance. This seminar will trace the advent of dramatic naturalism and realism, the contrary movement toward expressionist urgency and symbolist subtlety, the efforts of socially-engaged playwrights to respond to history and contemporary politics, and the opening of drama to the ambiguities of religion and philosophy. Plays and other writings by Henrik Ibsen, August Strindberg, Anton Chekhov, George Bernard Shaw, Bertolt Brecht, and Samuel Beckett. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ENGL
title: Modern American Drama
description: Online Course. In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENGL
title: Investigative Journalism
description: Techniques of in-depth reporting, ranging from interviews and document research to journalistic storytelling; the evolution of "muckraking" in the United States; and the ethical, philosophical, and political issues raised by such work. Improvement of the students' practical research and narrative skills through weekly assignments and a term-long writing project. Designed equally for those with journalistic experience and for those with skills in other arenas. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled.

subject: ENGL
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled.

subject: ENVE
title: Energy, Engines and the Enviro...
description: Energy sustainability and global warming; thermodynamic fundamentals; engines (combustion technologies, fossil-fuel pollution, carbon capture and sequestration). Wind, solar, biomass, and other renewable energy sources. Designed for freshmen and sophomores in science and engineering and for non–science majors. Prerequisite: A score of 4 or 5 on Advanced Placement examinations in mathematics and/or science. 1 Credit. Tuition: 3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: EP&E
title: Lies and Deception
description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: EPH
title: Summer Internship
description: The Internship is a degree requirement that is completed in the summer between the first and second academic years. Students work with their faculty advisers, the Career Management Center, and the Office of Public Health Practice to identify suitable public health placements such as medical care facilities, community agencies, public health departments, research projects, laboratories, and other sites engaged in public health activities. The internship experience sometimes serves as a basis for the M.P.H. thesis. The internship is displayed on the transcript with a grade of "S" (Satisfactory) upon completion. A course unit is not given for the summer internship. All students, with the exception of those in the Advanced Professional M.P.H. Program and the Accelerated M.B.A./M.P.H. Program, must complete an approved Summer Internship. The Summer Internship may be used to complete the practice requirement for the M.P.H. degree with prior approval from the Office of Public Health Practice.

subject: ER&M
title: Television and Crime
description: Not available

subject: ER&M
title: U.S. Border and Immigration Po...
description: U.S. border and immigration policies at the national, state, and local levels from the colonial period to the present. The historical evolution of border and immigration policy; contemporary debates; the effects of shifting policy on immigrants of varying legal statuses. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: EVST
title: Energy, Engines and the Enviro...
description: Energy sustainability and global warming; thermodynamic fundamentals; engines (combustion technologies, fossil-fuel pollution, carbon capture and sequestration). Wind, solar, biomass, and other renewable energy sources. Designed for freshmen and sophomores in science and engineering and for non–science majors. Prerequisite: A score of 4 or 5 on Advanced Placement examinations in mathematics and/or science. 1 Credit. Tuition: 3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: EVST
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Tours of energy facilities on the Yale campus. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 28 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: EVST
title: Sustainability and Institutions
description: Sustainable development as it relates to institutional change, decision-making processes, and systems thinking. Throughout the course we will explore the question of how organizations have the capacity to advance principles of sustainable development in their operational functions, mission and growth. The students will engage with Yale as a Living Laboratory throughout the course as well as visit one to two peer institutions in the region. Course lectures and discussions will draw from Yale's sustainability commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, implement a transportation demand management system, serve sustainable and local food in the residential colleges, build sustainable buildings, integrate sustainability into the master plan framework, reduce waste, and manage the urban campus via an ecosystem services framework. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: EVST
title: Environmental Inequalities
description: Examination of the intersection of environmental issues and various systems of social injustice, especially racism, sexism, and economic inequality. Topics include why and how minority communities face higher levels of environmental risk; the role grassroots activism plays in mitigating unequal representation; which groups bear disproportionate shares of negative environmental consequences globally; and the role of art in the struggle for environmental justice. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: EVST
title: Global Environmental Governance
description: The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: EVST
title: Future of Food: Global Food Ch...
long_title: Future of Food: Global Food Challenges
description: This course is part of the IARU Global Summer Program. This course is open to Yale students and other IARU members only. This seminar will explore significant environmental, health, and energy challenges posed by global food production. These challenges all have complex histories of corporate innovation, law and regulation, scientific inquiry, confidential information, highly profitable markets, international trade, broad public acceptance, global environmental contamination, human exposure to hazardous substances, and abuse of labor, immigrants, and animals. They all offer insight into what might be a future of “responsible food.” 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: F&ES
title: Global Environmental Governance
description: The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: FILM
title: In Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film...
long_title: In Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, language, and film-making practicum. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students choose either FILM or CZEC credit. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Prague and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: June 26 - July 28.

subject: FILM
title: Cinematic Storytelling in Prague
description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Intensive, hands-on exploration of film history, theory and practice, offered in partnership with FAMU, the national film and television academy of the Czech Republic, Europe’s top film school. Theory, tools, and techniques and practical skills—from operating a 16mm film camera to recording dialogue to lighting a set—which they will apply in the production of a weekly film project. During the third week of the program, students will travel to the beautiful spa town of Karlovy Vary (Carlsbad) to attend the world-renowned Karlovy Vary International Film Festival. The program includes a two-week mini course in Czech language and culture. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Prague and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,800. Course Dates: June 5 - July 7.

subject: FILM
title: Quentin Tarantino
description: This class covers the entire directorial career of Quentin Tarantino, from his first film Reservoir Dogs (1992), to his most recent, The Hateful Eight (2015). We examine the formal elements that comprise Tarantino’s style, paying particular attention to his engagement with genre (the western, the martial arts film etc.). An introduction to basic film analysis and to cinematic terminology is included. The treatment of race and gender in his films is also scrutinized. Students encounter a range of approaches to Tarantino’s films, in order to interrogate why his works are both lauded and condemned. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: FILM
title: Sports and Media
description: A study of the interrelations among popular sport, cinema, television, radio, print, and social media. Explores topics of identity, commerce, and civics through contemporary texts (Hunger Games, Senna, Invictus), and introduces the history of sport in media culture. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: FILM
title: Money and Media: The Business...
long_title: Money and Media: The Business of Hollywood
description: An examination of the key events and ideas that shape the modern motion picture business from financial, institutional, and historical standpoints. Topics include ways that the business has evolved in response to changes in technology, distribution, and competition; how the business dictates what ends up on screen; and relationships among studios, actors, agents, independent filmmakers, distributors, and the viewing audience. Industry practitioners discuss special topics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: FILM
title: Film, Video, and American Hist...
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Civil War and Reconstruction, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, the Reagan era, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include films such as The Birth of a Nation, Modern Times, Dr. Strangelove, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: FILM
title: Global Hollywood
description: This course focuses on the ways in which Hollywood both participates in and represents the processes of globalization. Through a series of case studies, we examine the dynamics of the Hollywood industry today, including Hollywood’s strategies for securing emerging film markets such as China, and multiplying its revenue streams through product placement, branding, franchising, and merchandising. Some of the films we will consider are: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Kill Bill, Slumdog Millionaire, Syriana, Traffic, and Avatar. Will Hollywood refashion the world in its image or will the requirements of pleasing diverse world audiences refashion Hollywood? 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: FILM
title: Screenwriting
description: This course will look at the screenplay as both a literary text and blue-print for production. Several classic screenplays will be analyzed. Students will then embark on pitching, outlining and writing their own scripts. We will intensively focus on character development, creating "cinematic" dialogue, plot construction, conflict, pacing, dramatic foreshadowing, the element of surprise, text and subtext and visual story-telling. Several classic and contemporary films will first be read and then screened for analysis and discussion. (Psycho, Chinatown, Blade Runner, Winter's Bone, The Devil Wears Prada, The Social Network). Students will learn professional screenplay format and write an 8-12 page screenplay that will be read aloud in class and critiqued. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: FILM
title: Television and Crime
description: Examines crime dramas, reality television, news coverage, and crime documentaries. Analysis of how popular media shapes public views on criminality, law enforcement, violence, due process, and judicial responsibility. Pays attention to the historical relationship between media, crime, and the politics of race, class, gender, and sexuality. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: FREN
title: Elementary and Intermediate Fr...
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Paris, France. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French. Focuses on developing language skills, communicative proficiency, self-expression, and cultural insights through extensive use of authentic audio, video material, and field trips. Conducted entirely in un-simplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work, and all field trips are required. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S120. Enrollment limited. Priority is given to Yale undergraduate students. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of FREN S120). Tuition: $3,900. Course Dates: May 29 - July 28.

subject: FREN
title: Elementary and Intermediate Fr...
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Paris, France. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French. Focuses on developing language skills, communicative proficiency, self-expression, and cultural insights through extensive use of authentic audio, video material, and field trips. Conducted entirely in un-simplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work, and all field trips are required. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S110. Enrollment limited. Priority is given to Yale undergraduate students. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 credits. Tuition: $3,900. Course Dates: May 29 - July 28.

subject: FREN
title: Intermediate and Advanced Fren...
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Paris, France. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Prerequisite: FREN 120 (Elementary and Intermediate French II), 121 (Intermediate French) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S140. Enrollment limited. Priority is given to Yale undergraduate students. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of FREN S140). Tuition $3,900. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: FREN
title: Intermediate and Advanced Fren...
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Paris, France. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Prerequisite: FREN 120 (Elementary and Intermediate French II), 121 (Intermediate French) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S140. Enrollment limited. Priority is given to Yale undergraduate students. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition $3,900. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced Culture and Conversat...
description: Offered in Paris, France. An advanced language course intended to improve students' comprehension of spoken and written French as well as their speaking and writing skills.
