Excursions to museums, movies, and theaters complement the reading of modern fiction and nonfiction texts. Prerequisite: FREN 140 (Intermediate and Advanced French II), FREN 145 (Intensive Intermediate and Advanced French), a score of 5 on the AP exam, a satisfactory placement test score, or or equivalent proficiency proficiency. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1. Tuition: $3,900. Course Dates: May 22 - June 23.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced Culture and Conversat...
description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. In small groups, students conduct surveys and interviews, melding the techniques of ethnography and photojournalism. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings; discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals; films; songs; stories; and clips from French television. Prerequisite: FREN 150 (Advanced Language Practice), a score of 5 on the AP exam, a satisfactory placement test score, or equivalent proficiency proficiency. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1. Tuition: $3,900. Course Dates: May 22 - June 23.

subject: FREN
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual, social, and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose FREN, HUMS, or LITR credit. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: July 3 - August 4.

subject: FREN
title: Belle Époque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Époque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, and Feydeau. Students choose FREN, HUMS, or LITR credit. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: May 29 - June 30.

subject: G&G
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Tours of energy facilities on the Yale campus. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 28 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: GLBL
title: The Balance of Power: Theory a...
long_title: The Balance of Power: Theory and Practice
description: Explores the evolution of the international balance of power since the outset of the twentieth century. The causes and conduct of World Wars I and II and the Cold War, as well as the evolution of international politics since the demise of the Soviet Union. Emphasis is both analytical and historical. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: GLBL
title: Introduction to Human Rights T...
long_title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: GMAN
title: Intermediate German I
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Berlin, Germany. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 (Elementary German II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Berlin and all other expenses beyond tuition. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of GMAN S140). Tuition: $3,900. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: GMAN
title: Intermediate German II
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Berlin, Germany. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 (Elementary German II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S130. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Berlin and all other expenses beyond tuition. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $3,900. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: GMAN
title: The Logic of Dreams
description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: GMAN
title: Psychological Disciplines and...
description: The complex function and effects of the aesthetical regime. Brings together two periods of psychological approaches on beauty and the arts: discussions of psychology of the arts in 18th-century England, Germany and France with the 20th-century discussions from Freud and Lacan to empirical psychology. Theoretical texts (including Freud, Jung, Fechner), painting (from Raffaello to Dali), photography (from Man Ray to Jeanloup Sieff) literature (from Rousseau to Doeblin), as well as opera and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: GMAN
title: German for Reading
description: Offered online. Students acquire skills for reading German-language texts of any difficulty with some fluency. Study of syntax and grammar; practice in close reading and translation of texts in different genres in the humanities. Yale doctoral student tuition is funded by GSAS. Visiting student tuition: $800. May 22 - June 23.

subject: GMST
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: July 3- August 4.

subject: HIST
title: Civil War and Reconstruction
description: The causes and consequences of the American Civil War. A search for the multiple meanings of a transformative event, including national, sectional, racial, constitutional, social, gender, intellectual, and individual dimensions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: HIST
title: Social Movements in U.S. History
description: Investigates the history of movements for social change in American history. Examines how they have arisen, how they have chosen strategies for advancement and goals to accomplish, and how they have ended. Movements include abolitionism, workers' rights, communism and anticommunism, civil rights and black power, feminism, gay liberation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: HIST
title: Film, Video, and American Hist...
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Civil War and Reconstruction, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, the Reagan era, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include films such as The Birth of a Nation, Modern Times, Dr. Strangelove, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: HIST
title: From Crusade to Enlightnement:...
long_title: From Crusade to Enlightnement: Medieval & Early Modern Europe
description: A survey of Western Europe from the late medieval period to the eighteenth century. Major topics include the Crusades, late medieval heretical movements, the Protestant and Catholic Reformations, the wars of religion, the seventeenth-century witch craze, and the rise of secularism and tolerance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: HIST
title: The Cold War: A Global History
long_title: The Cold War: A Global History
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: HIST
title: History of Southeastern Europe
description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Dubrovnik and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1. Tuition: $3,800. Course Dates: July 3 - August 4.

subject: HIST
title: Modern Latin America
description: This course follows the news out of present-day Latin America to investigate the history of the region from the independence movements of the early nineteenth century through the present. We will examine recent headlines on the death of Fidel Castro and the opening of US-Cuban relations, the Puerto Rican debt crisis, the Colombian Peace Accords, ecotourism in Chile, and anti-immigrant and anti-Mexico sentiment in the recent U.S. elections. We will use these headlines to launch into historical case studies of the Caribbean, Mexico, Colombia, and Chile in order to gain a deeper understanding of the region's past and present. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: HSAR
title: Introduction to History of Art...
long_title: Introduction to History of Art:  Renaissance to Present
description: Painting, sculpture, and graphic arts, with some reference to architecture. Selected major works and artists treated in terms of form, function, and historical context. Introduction to visual analysis. Special attention to contact between Europe and its others. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: HSAR
title: Contemporary Art
description: Art from 1950 to the present and recent historical precedents that have shaped current artistic practices. Topics include pop art, land art, conceptual art, appropriation, institutional critique, video, installations, relational aesthetics, and feminist practice, amongst others. Focusing mostly on work made in the United States and Europe, but also considers the emergence of a global art market through art fairs, biennials, and artistic collectives and collaborations. Seminar discussions are enhanced with frequent visits to the Yale University Art Gallery and Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: HSAR
title: Psychological Disciplines and...
description: The complex function and effects of the aesthetical regime. Brings together two periods of psychological approaches on beauty and the arts: discussions of psychology of the arts in 18th-century England, Germany and France with the 20th-century discussions from Freud and Lacan to empirical psychology. Theoretical texts (including Freud, Jung, Fechner), painting (from Raffaello to Dali), photography (from Man Ray to Jeanloup Sieff) literature (from Rousseau to Doeblin), as well as opera and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: HSHM
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Disability and Deviance in the United States
description: Cancelled. Traces the history of disability, as well as its relationship to ideas of normal and deviant personhood, in the United States, focusing on the period from the mid-nineteenth century to the present. Examines how differences in bodies and abilities have been interpreted in the past, and how they might be approached in the future. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: HUMS
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart & Fri...
description: Online Course. The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: HUMS
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: HUMS
title: Belle Époque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Époque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, and Feydeau. Students choose FREN, HUMS, or LITR credit. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: May 29 - June 30.

subject: HUMS
title: The Logic of Dreams
description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: HUMS
title: Rome
description: Offered in Rome, Italy. Designed as the logical complement and correlation to HUMS 444, this course will consider how Rome's contributions to Western thought are recorded in the very fabric of the city. Prerequisite: HUMS 444 (City of Rome). Students not enrolled in the 2017 Spring “City of Rome” course (HUMS 444) should contact the program instructor (see above) to determine if they have a satisfactory background in the program’s subject matter to apply. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Open to Yale students only. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Rome and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition $7,600. Course dates: May 29 - June 30.

subject: HUMS
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual, social, and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose FREN, HUMS, or LITR credit. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: July 3 - August 4.

subject: IDRS
title: IndependentResearchintheSummer...
description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students only. Independent Research in the Summer consists of special projects set up by the student in an area of particular interest with the help of a faculty adviser and the director of undergraduate studies, intended to enable the student to cover material not otherwise offered by the department. The course may be used for research, design projects, or for directed reading, but in all cases a term paper, written report on the research project, or its equivalent is normally required as determined by the faculty advisor and DUS. The student must meet regularly with the faculty adviser. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty advisor, who should also supply a 1- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences for students in STEM, or the Dean of Summer Session for students in the Humanities or Social Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. All approvals may be submitted via email to summer.session@yale.edu with IDRS S300 and the student’s name in the subject line. Students taking Independent Research in the Summer for 1 credit should expect to spend approximately 35 hours a week on their research for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students should expect to spend approximately 35 hours a week on their research for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 – June 30/Session B: July 3-August 4.

subject: IDRS
title: IndependentResearchintheSummer...
description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students only. subject: IDRS
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a l- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: IDRS
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a l- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian I
description: Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Siena, Italy. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120. Enrollment limited. Priority is given to Yale undergraduate students. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Siena and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (Credit only on completion of ITAL S120). Tuition $3,900. Course dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ITAL
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Siena, Italy. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120. Enrollment limited. Priority is given to Yale undergraduate students. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Siena and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (Credit only on completion of ITAL S120). Tuition $3,900. Course dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian II
description: Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Siena, Italy. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S110. Enrollment limited. Priority is given to Yale undergraduate students. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Siena and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $3,900. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ITAL
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Siena, Italy. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture.
