Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Siena and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $3,900. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian I
description: Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Siena, Italy. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S140 and ITAL S152. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Siena and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of ITAL S140). Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian I
description: Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Siena, Italy. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S140 and ITAL S152. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Siena and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of ITAL S140). Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian II
description: Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Siena, Italy. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S130 and ITAL S152. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Siena and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian II
description: Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Siena, Italy. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice, and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S130 and ITAL S152. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Siena and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ITAL
title: History, Culture, and Film in...
long_title: History, Culture, and Film in Tuscany
description: Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and five weeks in Siena, Italy. Critically examine the cultural identity of Tuscany, as manifested in its history, art, architecture, and folklore, with a special focus on Siena. Literary and historical readings, cinematic representations of Tuscany, in-depth tours of the city's monuments and museums, as well as field trips to Florence, San Gimignano, Pisa, and the Tuscan countryside. Particular attention will be devoted to the defining ritual of Sienese life: Il Palio, the splendid medieval horse race run in the city's central Piazza del Campo. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S130-ITAL S140. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Siena and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1. Tuition: See ITAL S130 & ITAL S140. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: ITAL
title: CANCELLED
description: Cancelled. Offered in Siena, Italy. The origins, development, and maturation of the Renaissance in Florence. The city's political debates, ideals of education, Neoplatonic enthusiasms, literature, and art. The Florentine Renaissance compared to those of Ferrara and Rome. Includes visits to Florence, Rome, and Ferrara. ITAL 140 (Intermediate Italian II) or 145 (Intensive Intermediate Italian) or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: June 19 - July 21.

subject: LATN
title: Beginning Latin: The Elements...
long_title: Beginning Latin: The Elements of Grammar
description: Introduction to Latin. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for LATN 120. No prior knowledge of Latin assumed. Credit only on completion of LATN S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: LATN
title: Beginning Latin: Review of Gra...
long_title: Beginning Latin: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
description: Continuation of LATN 110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Latin authors. The sequence LATN 110, 120 prepares for 131 or 141. Prerequisite: LATN 110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: LING
title: Introduction to Linguistics
description: Introduction to the scientific study of language as a cognitive and social system. Basic concepts in the structure of language: phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics. The relation of linguistics to psychology, neuroscience, anthropology, and other disciplines. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: LITR
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: LITR
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual, social, and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose FREN, HUMS, or LITR credit. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: July 3 - August 4.

subject: LITR
title: Belle Époque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Époque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, and Feydeau. Students choose FREN, HUMS, or LITR credit. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: May 29 - June 30.

subject: LITR
title: Psychological Disciplines and...
description: The complex function and effects of the aesthetical regime. Brings together two periods of psychological approaches on beauty and the arts: discussions of psychology of the arts in 18th-century England, Germany and France with the 20th-century discussions from Freud and Lacan to empirical psychology. Theoretical texts (including Freud, Jung, Fechner), painting (from Raffaello to Dali), photography (from Man Ray to Jeanloup Sieff) literature (from Rousseau to Doeblin), as well as opera and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: LITR
title: The Logic of Dreams
description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3-August 4.

subject: LITR
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Surveillance, Paranoia, and the Modern State
description: Cancelled. Examines the literary and cinematic reaction to the collection and control of information and the tension that arises between these practices and liberal claims to privacy rights. Attention to the theoretical relationship between writers, authors, spectators and their objects. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: MATH
title: Calculus of Functions of One V...
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I
description: Online Course. Limits and their properties. Definitions and some techniques of differentiation and the evaluation of definite integrals, with applications. Use of the software package Mathematica to illustrate concepts. No prior acquaintance with calculus or computing assumed. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: MATH
title: Calculus of Functions of One V...
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II
description: A continuation of MATH 112. The definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, polar coordinates, Taylor series, applications. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: MATH
title: Introduction to Functions of S...
long_title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
description: Calculus of functions of several variables, with some linear algebra. Intended for students in the social sciences, especially those majoring in Economics. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). Yale students may not take this course after MATH 120 or 222. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: MATH
title: Calculus of Functions of Sever...
long_title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables
description: Analytic geometry in three dimensions, using vectors. Real-valued functions of two and three variables, partial derivatives, gradient and directional derivatives, level curves and surfaces, maxima and minima. Parametrized curves in space, motion in space, line integrals; applications. After MATH 115 or with permission of instructor. May not be taken after MATH 121. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: MCDB
title: Laboratory for Principles of M...
long_title: Laboratory for Principles of Molecular, Cell, and Developmental Biology
description: Experimental techniques and procedures in molecular and cell biology. Must be taken after BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or after BIOL S105. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1950. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: MCDB
title: Cell Biology
description: A comprehensive course in cellular and molecular biology. Emphasis on general principles of cell function and rationale and design of pertinent biomedical experiments. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or BIOL S105, or permission of the instructor. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29-June 30.

subject: MCDB
title: Biochemistry
description: An introduction to the biochemistry of animals, plants, and microorganisms, emphasizing the relations of chemical principles and structure to the evolution and regulation of living systems. This course will be taught in an active learning format, whereby the typical lecture and homework elements of a course are reversed. Narrated Powerpoint video lectures are viewed by students at home before the class session, while in-class time is devoted to problem-solving exercises, collaborative projects and discussions. Prerequisites: BIOL 101, 102, 103, and 104 or MCDB 120 or MCDB 200; one term of organic chemistry. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: MCDB
title: Neurobiology
description: Introduction to neuroscience, divided into 3 course modules: 1) Cellular neurophysiology, addressing the excitable properties of neurons and the function of synapses, 2) Systems neurobiology, examining neural circuits as they relate to the functional properties of the nervous system, with each system that is addressed examined in detail, and 3) Neural development and plasticity, examining the cellular and molecular mechanisms governing neural development, plasticity, and the establishment of memory. Prerequisites: introductory course in biology (BIOL 101-104) and at least 1 semester of college chemistry, or permission of instructor. A course in physics or its equivalent is also recommended but not required. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3-August 4.

subject: MENG
title: Energy, Engines, and the Envir...
description: Energy sustainability and global warming; thermodynamic fundamentals; engines (combustion technologies, fossil-fuel pollution, carbon capture and sequestration). Wind, solar, biomass, and other renewable energy sources. Designed for freshmen and sophomores in science and engineering and for non–science majors. Prerequisite: A score of 4 or 5 on Advanced Placement examinations in mathematics and/or science. 1 Credit. Tuition: 3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: MENG
title: Introduction to Materials Scie...
description: This course will provide an introduction to materials science for both engineering and science majors. The first half of the class will introduce basic topics including atomic and molecular bonding, crystal structure, deformation, and stress, strain, and failure. The second half of the course will cover a selection of materials, including metals, ceramics, polymers, emulsions, and dispersions. Emphasis will be placed on "soft materials" that dominate our daily experiences with food, pharmaceuticals, personal care products, and even biological materials. Prerequisites: college-level introductory courses or equivalents in calculus, physics, and chemistry. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: MMES
title: Introduction to Islam
description: An introduction to Islam. Topics include Muhammad and the Qur'an; Muslim tradition and religious law; Islamic philosophy and theology; Shi'ism and Sufism; basic beliefs and practices of the Muslim community; religious institutions; and modern trends. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: MUSI
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart & Fri...
description: Online Course. The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: MUSI
title: Jazz, Race & Gender in America
description: Online Course. A study of the evolution of jazz, from its precursors in the music of Africa through its beginnings in New Orleans to its fusion with rock in the 1970s. Jazz's greatest artists and their styles are presented with selected music of each jazz period and a discussion of the gender, racial and sociological factors surrounding the genre's development. While no extensive music theory background or formal instrumental experience is required, students who can read music will be best prepared to fulfill the listening and form identification assignments. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: MUSI
title: EDM: Fundamentals
description: Online Course. The developmental history of technology in music creativity, with particular attention to the aesthetics and musical invention in the genres and repertoire of electronic dance music including: house, techno, trance, hip-hop, jungle, drum 'n' bass, dub step, drum step and trap, among others. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: NURS
title: Sem in Comm Hlth Nur & PH: Com...
long_title: Sem in Comm Hlth Nur & PH: Comnty Hlth Nrsng & Pblc Hlth
description: 2.5 credit hours. This course explores the multidisciplinary theoretical foundations that are the basis for community health nursing practice. Community health nurses provide preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitation, and hospice services across the life span. The clinical experience focuses on the delivery of these health services in community organizations. A community-as-partner assessment and diagnosis project, which culminates in identification of a community health problem and potential solutions, augments core seminar content. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Clinical Practice in Maternal-...
description: 2 credit hours. This course focuses on clinical practice essential to nursing care of women, newborns, and their families throughout the childbearing cycle and the neonatal period. Clinical settings include hospital and ambulatory care. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Seminar in Maternal-Newborn Nu...
description: 2 credit hours. This course presents theory essential to the provision of nursing care to childbearing families throughout the childbearing cycle, the neonatal period, and the pre- and inter-conceptional phases. Application of the nursing process as it relates to the promotion, maintenance, and restoration of health is emphasized. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Clinical Practice in Pediatric...
description: 2 credit hours. Utilizing a family-centered approach, this course provides clinical experience in identifying and assessing children's physiological and developmental needs, and planning, implementing, and evaluating a plan of nursing care to meet the needs of a particular child and his/her family in health care settings. Students have opportunities to use principles of growth and development, knowledge of the child's and family's physical and emotional responses to illness, and principles of pediatric nursing in caring for children and their families. The student gains skill and knowledge in the nursing role and an appreciation for the importance of utilizing research findings in practice and collaborating with other health professionals. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Seminar in Pediatric Nursing
description: 2 credit hours. This course presents theory essential to promote health and adaptation to illness for children and their families. Emphasis is placed on growth and development, as well as pathophysiological, social, environmental, and cultural factors that influence children's and families' response to health and illness. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Clinical Practice in Psychiatr...
long_title: Clinical Practice in Psychiatric–Mental Health Nursing
description: 2 credit hours. This course builds on skills learned in medical-surgical nursing by providing clinical experience in assessing, planning, implementing, and evaluating a plan of nursing care to meet the unique needs of patients with acute and chronic psychiatric disabilities across the life span. Students gain skills in the use of therapeutic communication, working with the interdisciplinary team, and implementing all phases of the nurse-patient relationship while applying concepts taught in 521. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Seminar in Psychiatric–Mental...
description: 2 credit hours. In combination with 520, this seminar provides the foundations of understanding and treating psychiatric disabilities within a bio-psycho-social-spiritual-cultural-theoretical framework of health promotion and disease prevention related to both mental health and mental illness. Course content includes the pathophysiology, assessment, diagnosis, treatment, and evaluation of cognitive, perceptual, emotional, behavioral, and interpersonal symptoms associated with common psychiatric diagnoses for individuals with mental illness and their families across the life span. Students analyze the economic, legal, and ethical issues that influence care in a variety of settings. Required of all students in the prespecialty year. Four hours per week, first half of spring or summer term, as assigned.

subject: NURS
title: Clinical Practice for Family a...
long_title: Clinical Practice for Family and Adult/Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioners
description:
4.5–6 credit hours. Course content includes clinical practice in health assessment and the provision of primary and focused health care. Students meet weekly for a one-and-one-half-hour clinical seminar that is held concurrently with clinical practice. Clinical seminar serves as a forum for students to present and discuss cases and explore issues encountered in clinical practice. Required of adult/gerontology primary care and family nurse practitioner students in the first year of specialization. Clinical seminar discussions for family nurse practitioner students focus on providing care for patients across the life span. AGPCNP discussions focus on caring for adult and gerontologic populations, including adolescents, adults, and older adults. Taken concurrently with 557b and, for family nurse practitioner students, with 635b. Eight to sixteen hours of clinical practice (fifteen weeks) and one and one-half hours of clinical seminar per week.
Prerequisite: all required courses in the fall term of the first specialty year.

subject: NURS
title: Women's Health II: Clinical Ca...
long_title: Women's Health II: Clinical Care of Women with Common Health Issues
description: 2 credit hours. This course provides students with increasing experience in ambulatory gynecologic and obstetrical settings for all women across the life span. Students have eight hours of clinical practice per week for fourteen weeks and attend clinical conference for one hour per week. The clinical seminar serves as a forum for students to explore issues encountered in clinical practice. Required of midwifery/women's health nurse practitioner students in the first year of specialization.

subject: NURS
title: Clinical Care of Childbirth
description: 2.5 credit hours. Students are provided with supervised clinical experience in labor, birth, newborn, and postpartum care. Students have twelve hours of clinical practice per week for twelve weeks and attend clinical conference for one hour per week. The clinical seminar serves as a forum for students to explore issues encountered in clinical practice. Required of midwifery students in the first year of specialization.

subject: NURS
title: Advanced Clinical Practice for...
long_title: Advanced Clinical Practice for Adult/Gerontology Primary Care and Family Nurse Practitioners
description:
6 credit hours. This clinical course builds upon the experiences gained in 556b and provides students further opportunity to develop advanced nursing skills, clinical judgment, and evidence-based patient management strategies necessary to manage common acute and chronic health care conditions. Students participate in designated weekly primary care clinical experiences arranged by faculty. In addition, students meet weekly for a one-and-one-half-hour clinical conference that is held concurrently with clinical practice. Clinical seminar discussions for family nurse practitioner students focus on family-centered care and providing care for patients across the life span. Clinical seminar discussions for all other students focus on providing patient-centered care for patients from adolescence to senescence. Clinical conference serves as a forum for students to present and discuss cases and explore issues encountered in clinical practice. Required of adult/gerontology primary care and family nurse practitioner students in the final year. Taken concurrently with 757a/b and, for family nurse practitioners, with 833a/b. Eight to sixteen hours of clinical practice per week (fifteen weeks), and one and one-half hours of clinical conference per week (each term).
Prerequisite (or concurrent with): 556b.

subject: NURS
title: Advanced Health Assessment in...
long_title: Advanced Health Assessment in Adult/Gerontology Acute Care
description:
3 credit hours. This course is designed to help students assimilate all the areas of women's health outpatient practice in a way that enables them to provide full-scope care with appropriate clinical supervision and academic support, including site preceptors, faculty, school, and library resources. During the course, students continue to refine their ability to provide high-quality, evidence-based practice within appropriate cultural contexts of care and to provide patient safety in clinical practice as they continue to be mindful of the responsibilities and accountability inherent in their emerging professional role. Students are expected to build on the knowledge and skills obtained in all previous courses. Required of midwifery/women's health nurse practitioner students in the final year of specialization. Minimum thirty-six hours per week of clinical practice (including 1:3-hour ratio for on-call time as negotiated with clinical preceptors, which is dependent on the clinical site and the student's ability to demonstrate clinical proficiency).
Prerequisites: all YSN core courses and all women's health core courses.

subject: NURS
title: Adult/Gerontology Acute Care C...
long_title: Adult/Gerontology Acute Care Clinical Practice I
description:
4.5 credit hours. This course is designed to help students assimilate all the areas of midwifery practice in a way that enables them to provide full-scope care with appropriate clinical supervision and academic support, including site preceptors, faculty, school, and library resources. During the course, students continue to refine their ability to provide high-quality, evidence-based practice within appropriate cultural contexts of care. They provide patient safety in clinical practice as they continue to be mindful of the responsibilities and accountability inherent in the emerging professional midwifery role. Students are expected to build on the knowledge and skills obtained in all previous courses. Required of midwifery students in the final year of specialization. Minimum thirty-six hours per week of clinical practice (including 1:3-hour ratio for on-call time as negotiated with clinical preceptors, which is dependent on the clinical site and the student's ability to demonstrate clinical proficiency).
Prerequisites: all YSN core courses and all midwifery core courses.

subject: NURS
title: Thry & Applctn of Proj Mgmt
description: 1.5 credit hours. This course provides an overview of theoretical principles and concepts essential to assessing, designing, implementing, and evaluating population-based health projects within and across the health system and other organizations. In this course, students critically examine change, decision making, evaluation, and management-related theories as a foundation for project planning, implementation, and evaluation of an evidence-based improvement project. Students identify and develop a theory-based project derived from an integrated synthesis of the literature. Students also identify appropriate software, tools, and communication techniques essential for leading an interprofessional team from inception to completion of the project within and across health care systems or other organizations. The tools and processes learned in this course will support work toward the subsequent capstone experience. Taught as an intensive during the summer intersession. Required of D.N.P. students in the first year.

subject: NURS
title: Achieving Population Health Eq...
description: 2 credit hours. This course provides a critical overview of the historical and contemporary health and health disparities research, relevant literature, and policies as essential context for understanding how to achieve health equity. The social and biological determinants of health and health disparities are also critically examined in light of political, economic, cultural, legal, and ethical issues. Selected health and health disparities population-based data are examined as a foundation for explicating how subpopulations experience disparate health across the life span. Students examine how past and current policies (state, federal, tribal), politics, population-based data findings, and selected frameworks enhance or act as barriers to achieving health equity with diverse populations, systems, and/or communities. Additionally, students design an organizational policy plan for achieving population health and health equity within a health system, organization, and/or community-based health system.

subject: PHIL
title: Happiness
description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time. How new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea. Whether happiness should be a goal in life. The relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PHIL
title: Friendship
description: Considers the nature and value of friendship. What is friendship? Does it consist in certain shared activities, the sharing of personal information, and the shaping of the self. How does friendship fit into our moral theories and what conflicts can develop between friendship and morality? 1 Credit. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy
description: Introduction to the history and methods of philisophical reflection and inquiry. Exploration of several perennial philosophical issues and the distinctive ways of addressing these issues through a close reading of historical texts and group discussion. Readings include selections from the works of Plato, Aristotle, Hume, Kant, Mill, and twentieth-century philosophers. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PHIL
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Online Course. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 29 - June 30 (CRN 30133) and Session B: July 3 - August 4 (CRN 30136).

subject: PHIL
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Online Course. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 29 - June 30 (CRN 30133) and Session B: July 3 - August 4 (CRN 30136).

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Bioethics
description: A survey of questions in contemporary bioethics from a philosophical perspective. Topics include: end of life issues, such as euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide; beginning of life issues, such as abortion and pre-natal genetic screening; the ethics of human enhancement; and issues related to public health, such as organ donation and the distribution of scarce resources. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to the Philosophy...
long_title: Introduction to the Philosophy of Education
description: Explores three central areas of the Philosophy of Education: the aims and purposes of education; how one should educate; and questions related to education, authority, and rights. Considered from both historical and contemporary perspectives, through careful readings of works by some of the field's most influential contributors (including Plato, Rousseau, Dewey, Freire, and Noddings). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PHIL
title: Eastern Philosophy
description: Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PHIL
title: Lies and Deception
description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PHYS
title: Science of Modern Technology
description: Examination of the science behind selected advances in modern technology and implications for public policy, with focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance. Topics are developed by the participants with the instructor and with guest lecturers, and may include nanotechnology, quantum computation and cryptography, renewable energy technologies, optical systems for communication and medical diagnostics, transistors, satellite imaging and global positioning systems, large-scale immunization, and DNA made to order. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PHYS
title: Energy, Technology and Society
description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Tours of energy facilities on the Yale campus. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 28 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S180, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students and beyond. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,950. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture courses PHYS S171 and PHYS S181, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students and beyond. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,950. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers Newtonian mechanics, gravitation, waves, and thermodynamics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers electromagnetism, optics, special relativity, and quantum physics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.  May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. Prerequisite: PHYS 180 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PLSC
title: The Global Politics of Artific...
long_title: The Global Politics of Artificial Intelligence
description: Study of the processes in which machine intelligence transforms economic, societal, and global politics and of the political challenges in development of beneficial artificial intelligence. Topics include the provably of beneficial AI; the effects on, and of, inequality and unemployment; military conflict and strategy with autonomous weapons, cyber weapons, and AI-enabled intelligence; and determining which global institutions are best suited for providing global public goods, the legitimate aggregation of preferences, and the control of AI development. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PLSC
title: The Balance of Power: Theory a...
long_title: The Balance of Power: Theory and Practice
description: Explores the evolution of the international balance of power since the outset of the twentieth century. The causes and conduct of World Wars I and II and the Cold War, as well as the evolution of international politics since the demise of the Soviet Union. Emphasis is both analytical and historical. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PLSC
title: Introduction to Human Rights T...
long_title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PLSC
title: Global Environmental Governance
description: The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PLSC
title: International Human Rights and...
description: International human rights organizations and their implications for international politics. The role of human rights institutions in affording remedies to victims of state abuse. The emergence and exercise of international human rights law, including its nature, mechanisms, and logic. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PLSC
title: The Cold War
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PLSC
title: Terrorism and Counterterrorism
description: Examination of the origins and evolution of modern terrorism, the challenges posed by terrorist groups to states and to the international system, and strategies employed to confront and combat terrorism. Assessment of a variety of terrorist organizations and the multidimensional causes of terrorist violence. Analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of counterterrorism strategies, with a particular focus on ways in which the threat of global terrorism might affect the healthy functioning of democratic states. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PLSC
title: Crime and Punishment
description: Topics in the history, theory, and realities of crime and punishment in the contemporary United States. Focus on various theories of criminal process in light of empirical evidence, the politicization of crime, civil rights issues, psychiatry and the law, abortion, and arguments about prison reform. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PLSC
title: Reading the Constitution
description: Online Course. Intensive introduction to the written Constitution, revolving tightly around two books authored by the instructor--America's Constitution: A Biography (2005) and America's Unwritten Constitution: The Precedents and Principles We Live By (2012). Provides detailed knowledge of America's written Constitution and considers various techniques of constitutional interpretation. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PLSC
title: Lies and Deception
description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PLSC
title: War and Constitutions
description: Examines the historical record from ancient times to the present to understand how wars have shaped the nation state, including structures of accountability and political rights. Provides students with the analytical and empirical tools for understanding the effects of war on constitutional structures across time and place. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PORT
title: Elementary Portuguese for Spea...
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages I
description: Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven), one week in Paraty, and the final four weeks in Rio de Janeiro, with homestays. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Prerequisite: knowledge of another Romance language. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S122 and PORT S352. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Brazil and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of PORT S122). Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: PORT
title: Elementary Portuguese for Spea...
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages II
description: Three weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven), one week in Paraty, and the final four weeks in Rio de Janeiro with homestays. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Prerequisite: knowledge of another Romance language. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112 and PORT S352. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Brazil and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: PORT
title: Introduction to Brazil
description: Three weeks in New Haven, one week in Paraty, final four weeks in Rio de Janeiro with homestays. An introduction to Brazilian cultural history from 1500 to the present. Essential themes and figures for understanding modern Brazil with emphasis on Rio de Janeiro. Includes cultural excursions. Conducted in English with use of Portuguese in Brazil. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Brazil and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1. Tuition: See PORT S112 & PORT S122. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Psychology
description: A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, and social bases of behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Psychology
description: Online Course. A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, social, and emotional bases of behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PSYC
title: Human Emotion
description: Introduction to major discoveries and theories of human emotion. Evolutionary theories of the origins of emotion; culture, sex and gender influences; emotion and morality; brain basis of emotion; sleeping and feeling; relationship between emotion and thinking; love and relationships; development of emotion; animal vs. human emotion; abnormal emotions in mental illness; and happiness. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PSYC
title: Mental Lives of Babies and Ani...
long_title: Mental Lives of Babies and Animals
description: Online Course. Interdisciplinary exploration of the cognitive, social, and emotional capacities of creatures lacking language and culture. The extent to which our complex psychology is unique to mature humans; the relative richness of a mental life without language or culture. Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PSYC
title: The Criminal Mind
description: Online Course. Covers the range of theoretical and empirical material that relates to the understanding of the criminal mind. Four main topics will be covered: personality and psychopathological factors associated with criminal behavior; theoretical and psychobiological explanations of crime; the interaction between biology and environment; the impact of psychobiological models for policy and intervention. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Technology fee $85. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PSYC
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Online Course. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 29 - June 30 (CRN 30132) and Session B: July 3 - August 4 (CRN 30135).

subject: PSYC
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Online Course. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3900. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 29 - June 30 (CRN 30132) and Session B: July 3 - August 4 (CRN 30135).

subject: PSYC
title: Drugs, Brain, and Behavior
description: Online Course. Introduction to the scientific study of psychoactive drugs (e.g., drugs that affect the mind). Drug use in modern society and the basic neurobiology related to neurotransmission and drug effects. Pharmacological and neurobiological mechanisms of different classes of legal, illegal, and medicinal drugs, including alcohol, caffeine, tobacco, stimulants, depressants, anti-depressants, pain-killers, and hallucinogens. Common misconceptions, drug effects, addiction, medical use of marijuana, and America's drug policies. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PSYC
title: Culture, Behavior, and Brain
description: Interactive relationships between culture, behavior, and brain. Psychological paradigms and brain imaging methods that have been integrated to study cultural influences on cognitive and neural processes. Current knowledge/theory about the sociocultural brain, and future questions regarding the interactive relationships between culture, behavior, and brain. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: PSYC
title: Abnormal Psychology
description: Offered Online. Study of the major forms of psychopathology that appear in childhood and adult life. Topics include the symptoms of mental disorders; the etiology of disorders from a variety of perspectives (psychological, biological, and sociocultural); and issues pertaining to diagnosis and treatment. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: PSYC
title: Autism and Related Disorders
description: Online Course. Survey of current understandings and treatment of autism from infancy through adulthood. Topics include etiology, diagnosis and assessment, treatment and advocacy, and social neuroscience methods. Focus on ways in which research findings are integrated into diagnosis and treatment practices. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: RLST
title: Introduction to Islam
description: An introduction to Islam. Topics include Muhammad and the Qur'an; Muslim tradition and religious law; Islamic philosophy and theology; Shi'ism and Sufism; basic beliefs and practices of the Muslim community; religious institutions; and modern trends. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: RLST
title: From Crusade to Enlightnement:...
long_title: From Crusade to Enlightnement: Medieval & Early Modern Europe
description: A survey of Western Europe from the late medieval period to the eighteenth century. Major topics include the Crusades, late medieval heretical movements, the Protestant and Catholic Reformations, the wars of religion, the seventeenth-century witch craze, and the rise of secularism and tolerance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian I
description: Three weeks on the Yale Campus (New Haven) and five weeks in St. Petersburg, Russia. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Prerequisite: RUSS 120 (First-Year Russian II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S140 & RUSS S242. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from St. Petersburg and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of RUSS S140). Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 24.

subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian II
description: Three weeks on the Yale Campus (New Haven) and five weeks in St. Petersburg, Russia. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Prerequisite: RUSS 120 (First-Year Russian II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S130 & RUSS S242. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from St. Petersburg and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 24.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian I
description: Three weeks on the Yale Campus (New Haven) and five weeks in St. Petersburg, Russia. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Prerequisite: RUSS 140 (Second-Year Russian II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S151 & RUSS S242. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from St. Petersburg and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of RUSS S151). Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 24.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian II
description: Three weeks on the Yale Campus (New Haven) and five weeks in St. Petersburg, Russia. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Prerequisite: RUSS 140 (Second-Year Russian II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S150 & RUSS S242. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from St. Petersburg and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 24.

subject: RUSS
title: Fourth-Year Russian I
description: Three weeks on the Yale Campus (New Haven) and five weeks in St. Petersburg, Russia. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" program featuring language study at the fourth year level of Russian. Students who wish to apply need to first contact Professor Constantine Muravnik. Prerequisite: RUSS 151 (Third-Year Russian II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S242. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from St. Petersburg and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1. Tuition $7,600. Course dates: May 29 - July 24.

subject: RUSS
title: Russian Culture
description: Three weeks on the Yale Campus (New Haven) and five weeks in St. Petersburg, Russia. Explores the cultural history of the imperial Russian capital, founded by Peter the Great in the early eighteenth century as a window on Europe. Considers the semiotics of Petersburg through a careful reading of selected literary texts, both prose and poetry, including Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky, Blok, Bely, Gumilev, Akhmatova, Mandelstam, Khlebnikov, Mayakovsky, Kharms, and others, as well as some works of literary and cultural criticism. The classroom sessions are complimented with a rich selection of excursions and tours in and around St.Petersburg. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS S130-S140 or RUSS S150-S151 or RUSS S160. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from St. Petersburg and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1. Tuition: See RUSS S130 & RUSS S140 or RUSS S150 & RUSS S151 or RUSS S160. Course dates: May 29 - July 24.

subject: S&DS
title: Introduction to Statistics
description: An introduction to statistical reasoning. Topics include controlled experiments and observational studies; histograms and scatterplots, averages and standard deviations; measurement error, the normal approximation; correlation and regression; probability and chance variation; sampling, the Gallup Poll and Current Population Survey; tests of significance. Focus on understanding concepts rather than mathematical manipulation. No formal mathematical prerequisite. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900 Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: SCIE
title: Scientific Research: Process a...
description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design and data interpretation, through lectures, reading and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions of preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative information. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 credit. Tuition: $3,900. May 30 - July 29.

subject: SOCY
title: Foundations of Modern Social T...
description: Major works of social thought that articulate the core ideas of sociology. Attention to social and historical contexts, conceptual frameworks and methods, and contributions to contemporary social analysis. Writers include Hobbes, Locke, J.S. Mill, Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, and Weber. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: SOCY
title: Global Public Health
description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation states. Mechanisms and challenges of incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: SOCY
title: Culture of Southeastern Europe
description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Dubrovnik and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1. Tuition: $3,800. Course Dates: July 3 - August 4.

subject: SOCY
title: The Making of Political News
description: Examines the processes through which political news gets made; how the form and content of political news are shaped in and through the ongoing relationships between political operatives and journalists; and the ways in which these actors attempt to structure and restructure such relationships to their benefit. 1 Credit. Tuition: S$3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Development of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S140 and S248. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from program site and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program pages. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of SPAN S140). Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Development of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S140 and S248. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from program site and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program pages. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of SPAN S140). Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish II
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Development of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S248. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from program site and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program pages. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish II
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Development of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S248. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from program site and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program pages. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $4,050. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: SPAN
title: Language, Culture, and Society...
long_title: Language, Culture, and Society of Spain
description: Offered in Valencia, Spain. A language program that explores historical and contemporary issues in Spanish culture. Set in Valencia, a city founded by the Romans 2,000 years ago, this course aims to reflect on both Spanish ancient heritage and modernity. Key works of literature will foster discussion on a wide range of topics such as the environment, the Mediterranean trade, politics and religion. Prerequisite: SPAN 140 (Intermediate Spanish II), 145 (Intensive Intermediate Spanish), a score of 5 on the AP exam, a placement test score of L5, or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Valencia and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: May 22 - June 23.

subject: SPAN
title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: Hi...
long_title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
description: Four weeks on the Yale campus (New Haven) and four weeks in Bilbao, Spain. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Classes will be held in the headquarters of the University of Deusto, located opposite the statuary and facing the Guggenheim Museum. Conducted in Spanish. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken concurrently with SPAN S130 and S140. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Bilbao and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1. Tuition: See SPAN S130 & SPAN S140. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili I
description: Offered in Arusha, Tanzania. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Prerequisite: SWAH 120 (Beginning Kiswahili II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2 (credit only on completion of SWAH S140). Tuition: $2,500. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili II
description: Offered in Arusha, Tanzania. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Prerequisite: SWAH 120 (Beginning Kiswahili II) or equivalent proficiency. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S130. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Arusha and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 1 1/2. Tuition: $2,500. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: SWAH
title: Advanced Kiswahili
description: Offered in Arusha, Tanzania. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140 (Intermediate Kiswahili II) or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Arusha and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $5,000. Course Dates: May 29 - July 21.

subject: THST
title: Introduction to Scenic Design
description: An introduction to the theory and practice of scenic design for theater. Topics include the history of scenic design; visual storytelling and theatricality; text analysis; the relationship between the designer, the director and the text; the role of the designer within the production process; methods for communicating design concepts (such as rendering, modeling and drafting); and considerations for evaluating a given design. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: THST
title: Modern European Drama
description: The major European playwrights active from 1879 (the premiere of Ibsen's A Doll’s House) to 1989 (the death of Beckett) were responsible for theatrical advances of continuing influence and importance. This seminar will trace the advent of dramatic naturalism and realism, the contrary movement toward expressionist urgency and symbolist subtlety, the efforts of socially-engaged playwrights to respond to history and contemporary politics, and the opening of drama to the ambiguities of religion and philosophy. Plays and other writings by Henrik Ibsen, August Strindberg, Anton Chekhov, George Bernard Shaw, Bertolt Brecht, and Samuel Beckett. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session B: July 3 - August 4.

subject: THST
title: Modern American Drama
description: In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: THST
title: Modern American Drama
description: Online Course. In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 29 - June 30.

subject: WGSS
title: Women, Food and Culture
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to the Peabody Museum, the Yale Farm, and the Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,900. Session A: May 29-June 30.

subject: WGSS
title: Men, Manhood, and Masculinity
description: Cultural and historic constructions of masculinity explored through an investigation of male bodies, sexualities, and social interactions. Multiple masculinities; the relationship between hegemonic, nonhegemonic, and subordinate masculinities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,900. Session A: May 29 - June 30.
